div.p:
XXXVII-
The Quango is said ^ by the natives to con-
-tain many venomous 22
water snakes which
congregate near the
carcase of any hippopotamus
that may be killed in
it - If this is true it
will account for all
the villages we saw
being situated far from
its banks - We were
advised to not to sleep
near it but as we were
anxious to cross to
the W^w/estern side we tried
to induce some of the
Bashinje to lend us
canoes for the purpose
This brought out the chief
of these parts who informed
us that all the canoe men
were his children and nothing
could be done without
hims authority - He then
made the ^usual demand for a
man, ^ an ox, or a gun adding
that without otherwise
one of ^ these we
must return to the country
from which we had
come - As I did not believe
this man had any power
23 over the canoes of the
other side and suspected
that if I gave him my
23
blanket the only thing I now
had in reserve - he might
leave us in the lurch after
all - I tried to persuade my
men to go at once to the
banks about two
miles off and have obtain
possession of the canoes
before we gave up the
blanket but they thought
that he mig this chief
might attack us in
the act of crossing
should we do so if we did so - The chief
came himself to our
encampment and made
his demand again - My
men stripped off the last
of their copper rings
and gave them - but
he was still intent on a
man - He thought as
others did that my
men were slaves - He
was a young man with
his wooly hair elaborately
dressed - That behind was
24 made up into a cone about
eight inches in diameter
at the base - carefully wound
swathed round with red and black
thread - As I resisted the
proposal to deliver up my
blanket untilluntil I had they had
placed us on the W^w/.estern
bank this chief continued
24
to worry us with his demands
till I was tired but my
little tent ^ was now in tatters
and having a wider hole
behind than the door in front
I in vain I tried to
lie down out of sight of
our persecutors - We
were on a reedy flat
and I could not follow
our/. our my usual plan of a
small stockade in which where
we had time to think
& concoct our plans
As I was trying to persuade
my men to move on
in spite of these people to
the bank a young half
breed blood Portuguese sergeant
of militia, Cypriano di
Abreu made his appearance
and gave the same advice
He had come across the
Quango in search of bees-
wax and assisted us in
making our arrangement
25 with the ferryman without
parting with my blanket

When we moved off
from thise chief who had
been plaguing us his people
opened a fire against
from ^ our sheds and continued
to blaze away some time
in the our direction we were going
25
but none of the bullets reached
us - It is probable that they
expected the demonstration
of the abundance of ammunition
they possessed would
make us run but when
we continued to move
quietly to the ford they
proceeded no farther
than our sleeping place.

Cypriano assisted us
in making a more satisfactory
arrangement with the ferrymen
than parting with my
blanket and as soon
as we reached the opposite
Bangala bank we were in the
territory of the Bangala
who are subjects of
the Portuguese and often
spoken of as
the Cassanges
or Cassantse and happily
all our difficulties with
the border tribes were
at an end -

Passing with light
hearts alothrough the high
grass forby a narrow
footpath for about three
miles to the wWest of the
26 river we came to several
neat square houses
and many cleanly looking
haf cross breaed Portuguese
standing in front of tothem
to salute us - They are all
26
enrolled in the Militia and
our friend Cypriano is
the commander of a
division established here -
The Bangala were very
troublesome to the Portuguese
traders and at last pro-
-ceeded so far as to kill
one of them when the
Government of Angola
at last sent an expedition
against them - which
being successful the
Bangala were dispersed
and are now returning
to their former abodes
The militia are settled
over them and engage
in trade and cultivation ^ agriculture/
for their support as no
pay is given to this
branch of the service
by the Government

We came to the dwelling
of Cypriano after it was
dark and I pitched my
little tent in front of it
27 for the night - We had
the company of mosquitoes
here though they do not
We never found them
troublesome on the
banks of the pure streams
of LŏndaLonda - On the morning
27
a small cyclopaedia and a
Portuguese dictionary - in which
the definition of a "Priest"
seemed ^ sounded ^ rather strange to a Protestant
vizvidelicet - "one who takes care of the
conscience"- They had also
a few tracts containing the
lives of the saints and Cypriano
had a few small images
of saints in wax in his room
One of these was St Ant^honySt Anthony
and a who had he endured
the privations he did in
his cell in looking after
these lost sheep would
have lived to better purpose
Neither Cypriano nor
his companions knew
what the bBible was but they had
relics in germanGerman
silver cases hung
round their necks
to act as charms
& save them from
danger by land or
by water in the
same way the
heathen have medicines - It is
a pity that the Church to
which they belong when
unable to attend to the
wants of her children
does not give them the
sacred writings in their
own tongue for it would
surely be better to see
them good protestants if these would
lead them
to be so than
29 to be idolators - entirely ignorant
of God's message to man.
For my part I would much
prefer to see the Africans
good Roman Catholics than
idolatrous heathen

28
Much of the civility shewnshown to
us here was no doubt owing
to the flattering letters of
recommendation I carried
from the Chevalier Du Prat
of Cape t^T/ownCape Town but I am
inclined to believe that my
friend Cypriano was influenced
too by feelings of genuine
kindness for he quite
bared his garden in
feeding us during the
few days which I remained
anxiously expecting
the clouds to disperse
so far as to allow of
my taking observations
for the determination
Quango of my the position ^ of the Quango but
the only the latitude could
be 9°, 50' South could be
ascertained but he slaughtered an
ox for us
and furnished
his mother and her maids
with manioc roots to
30 prepare "farina' for f
(farinha) for the four or
five days of our journey
Cassangé to Cassange - and never
hinted even
at payment -
My wretched
appearance must
have excited
his compassion The farina
is prepared by washing the
roots well then rasping
them down to a pulp -
Next day this is roasted
slightly on a metal plate
over a fire and is then
used with meat as a vegetable
29
It resembles closely wood sawings
and on that account is
named ("wood meal" It is
insipid and employed to
lick up any gravy remaining
on thone's plate - Those who
have become accustomed
to it relish it even after
they have returned to Europe

Den.tt.Dennett The manioc cultivated here
is of the sweet variety
The bitter with which were
were are accustomed in Londa,
is not to be found very
extensively in this fertile
valley - May is This was the beginning
of winter here, yet thmany
of the inhabitants were
busy sowing planting maize, - that
which we were now
eating was planted in in the
beginning of
beginning of February - The soil is
exceedingly fertile, and of
a dark red colour, -
31 and covered with such
a dense heavy crop of
coarse grass, that while ^ when
a marauding party of
Ambonda once came
into it for plunder while
it was in a dried state
the Bangala encircled
them ^ Amcommon enemy with a fire which
completely destroyed them -

30
This which is realated on the
authority of Portuguese who
were then in the country
I can reasily believe to
be true for the stalks of
the grass are generally
as thick as goose quills,
and no flight could
be made through the
mass of grass in any
direction where no
foot-path exists - Probably
in the case mentioned,
the direction of the wind
dr was such as to drive
the flames accross
the paths and prevent
escape flight ^ along them -

On one occasion
I nearly lost my waggon
by fire in a valley
where the grass was
only about three feet
high - We were roused
32 by the roar ^ as of as torrent
made by the fire
coming from the windward,
I immediately set fire to
that on our leeward,
and had just time to
drag the waggon on to
the bare space there,
before the windward
flames reached the
place where it had stood
31
which as ˄ the individuals are who
commit a petty depradationdepredation
in order to obtain the
shelter and food of a
prison, I gladly accompanied
Senhor de
Silva Rego him to the house of the
Commandant or Chefe
Senhor de Silva Rego - Having shewnshown
my passport to this gentlemen
he politely asked me to
supper, with him and as
we had eaten nothing
except the
farina eaten nothing but only the farinhafarina
only of Cypriano from the
Quango to this, I suspect
I appeared particularly
ravenous to the other
gentlemen around the table
They seemed, however,
to understand my position
pretty well from having
all travelled pretty extensively
themselves; - had they If they had
not been present I might
have put some in my
pocket to eat by night,
for after fever the
appetite is excessively
34 keen, - and manioc is
one of the most unsatisfying
kinds of food - Captain
Antonio Rodrigues Neves
then ˄ kindly invited me to take
up my abode in his
house - Next morning
this generous man arrayed
32
me in decent clothing, and con-
-tinued during the whole
period of my stay to treat
me as if I had been
his brother - I feel deeply
grateful to him for his
disinterested kindness, - for
he not only attended to
my wants, but ^ also furnished
food for my famishing
party - free of charge -

The village Cassangé
is composed of a number
thirty or forty traderstraders'
houses, which are large
and and scattered about without any regularity
on an elevated spot flat
spot in the great Quango
or Cassange valley without
any regularity - They
are built of wattle and
daub, and surrounded
by plantations of manioc,
maize &c - Behind
35 them there are usually
g ktcitchen gardens, in
which the common
European vegetable,
plaas potatoes, peas,
cababagescabbages, onions - Tomatoes
&c &c - grow - Guavas &
bananas and pine apples
appear, ^ from the size & abundance of the trees, to have been,
33
to have been introduced
many years ago while
the land was still in
the possession of the
natives - but pine apples,
orange, trees - fig - trees
and cashew strees seemhave been
but lately been tried - There
are about forty Portuguese
traders in this district,
all of whom are officers
in the militia, and many
of them have become
rich from the adopting
the plan of sending out
Pombeiros, or native traders,
with large quantities of
goods, to trade in the
more remote parts of
the country; - Several Governors
of some of the
Governors of
LoandaLuanda,
the capital of this, the
Kingdom
of Angola, Angola have insisted
on the observance of
a law which forbids from
motives of humanity
the Portuguese themselves
from passing beyond
the boundary. of the
kingdom They seem to
have taken it for granted,
36 that in cases where the
white trader was killed,
the agrgression had been
made by him, and they
wished to avoid the
necessity of punishing the
those who had shot been provok
34
provoked to shed Portuguese
blood - This indicates
a much greater liberality
of mind than has obtained
in our ^ own dealings with the
Caffres for we have
engaged in most expensive
wars with them without
once enquiring whether any
or perhaps all of the fault lay with
ourselves our frontier colonists - The Cassangé
traders seem inclined to
spread along the Quango
in spite of the desire of
their government to
keep them on one spot
for mutual protection
in case of war - and
if I might judge from
the week of feasting
I passed among them
they seem are generally
prosperous -

Wheeler As I always preferred
to appear in my own
37 proper character I was
an object of their curiosity
of these hospitable Portuguese
They evidently looked upon
me as an emissary agent
of the English Government
engaged in some new
movement for the suppression
of slavery ^ and ^ They could not divine what
35
a "missionar^ioymissionario" had to do
with the Latitudes and
Longitudes which I was
intent ofn observing,
When we became a little
familiar the questions put
by them were rather amusing
"Is it common for missionaries
to be doctors? Are you a doctor of medicine? do^uctor
of medicinaeo and a "doutor
of mathematico" too - ? You
must be more than a
missionary to know how
to takecalculate the Longitude!
Come tell us at once what
rank you hold in the
English army! They mThey may
have given credit to
my explanation of the
reasons for wearing
the moustache as that explains
why men
have beards
and women
have none but that
which puzzled many
besides my Cassangé
friends was the anomaly
of my being a "sacerdote"
with a wife & four
children! I usually got
38 rid of the thaet ^ last question by
putting another "Is it not
better to have the wife
with the children than
with the wife thea a wife and
children than to have the
children without a wife?"
36
But all were most kind
and hospitable and as
one of their festivals was
near they invited me to
partake of the feast -

The Anniversary of the
resurrection of our Saviour
was observed on the 16th April
as a day of rejoicing
though the Portuguese
have no priests at
Cassangé - The coloured
population dressed up a
figure intended to represent
Judas Iscariot and paraded
him on a riding ox about the village;
sneers and maledictions
were freely bestowed on
thus the poor wretch ^ thus represented -
The slaves and free coloured
population dressed in
their gayest
clothing made visits
to all the principal merchants
and wishing them "a good
feast" expected a present
in return - This wathough
frequently given in pigranted
39 in the shape of pieces of
calico to make new
dresses - was occasionally
refused but the rebuffs
did not much affect
the petitioner -

37
At ten we went to the residence
of the Commandant and
on a signal being given
two of the brafour brass guns
belonging to the Government
were commenced firing
& continued some time to
the great admiration of my
men - whose ideas of the
power of a cannon are very exalted,
The Portuguese flag was
hoisted and trumpets
sounded as an expression
of joy at the resurrection
of our Lord - Captain
Neves invited all the
principalit inhabitants
of the place, and he
did what he coulld
to feast them in a
princely style - All manner
of foreign preserved fruits - biscuits
wine beer
& wine from
Portugal - biscuits
from America
butter from
Cork and
beer from
England were
displayed and no expense
spared in rendering render the
entertainment joyous,
and ˄ Aafter the feast was
over they sat down
to the common enteamusement
of card-playing which
continued till eleven
oclocko'clock - As far as a
mere traveller could judge
they seemed to be plolite
40 and willing to aid each other

38
They live in a febrile district
and many of them had
enlarged spleens - they
have no ^ neither doctor nor
apothecary nor school
nor priest and when
taken ill trust to each
other and to Providence -
As Like men left in such
circumstances must
think for themselves
they have all a good
idea of what ought to
be done in the common
diseases of the country
and what they have
of either medicine or
skill they freely impart
to each other.

Not one of these
gentlemen had Portuguese
wives - They usually come
to Africa in order to make
a little money and return
to Lisbon - Hence they seldom
bring their wives with
them and never
can be
successful
colonists in
consequence but iIt is common
for them to have families
by native women - It
was particularly gratifying
to me who had beenam familiar
with the stupid prejudice
41 against colour, entertained
only by those who are
themselves becoming tawny
39
to view the liberality with
which people of colour
were treated by the Portuguese
Instances in which
cross breed ^ children of are abandoned,
trtranspose so common in the
south, isare here extremely
rare - They are acknowledged
by their fathers and at
at table and provided for
by their fathers as if
European - The ^ coloured clerks
of the merchants sat at
the same table with
their employers without
any embarassmentembarrassment - The
kind deportcivil manners
of superiors to inferiors
is probably the result
of the position they occupy
a few whites among
thousands of blacks but
nowhere else in Africa
is there so much good
will between Europeans
and natives as here -
If certain border ^ some borderEnglish colonists had
the absolute the certainty of ^ our Government
declining to bear them
out in their arrogance
we should probably he
42 hear less of Caffre grievances
insolence elsewhere - It is
insolence which begets insolence

Mead From the village of Cassangé
we have a good view
of the surrounding country -
It is a gently undulating
plain covered with grass
and patches of Forest -
The western edge of thise
Quango valley abppears
tw about twenty miles
off as if it were a
range of lofty mountains
and passes by the name
of Tala Mungongo "behold
the range" - In mythe old
Portuguese map to which I had
been trusting in planning
my route it is indicated
as Talla Mugongo or "Castle of
rocks"! and the Coanza
is put down as rising
therefrom but here I was
assured that the Coanza
had its source near
Bihe far to our the South
West of this and we
should not see that river
till we were came near
43 Pungo Andongo - It is somewhat
remarkable that more accurate
information has not been
published given about this country,
for Captain Neves & others
had an accurate ^ correct idea of
the courses theof the rivers and
communicated their knowledge
41
freely yet about this time
maps were sent to Europe
representing the Quango and
Coanza as the same
river and Cassangé placed
about one hundred miles
distant from its true position
The frequent recurrence
of the same name has
probably helped to increase
the confusion - I have
crossed several Quangos
but all insignificant except
that to which drains
this valley - The repititionrepetition
of the ^ favourite names of chiefs ^ as Catendé is
also perplexing one Catende
for instance may be ...
mistaken for another
for another as readily as
one20 Donal MacDonald is
the ^ same Highland Regent our two Sir Charles Napiers
for each other - To avoid
this confusion as much
as possible I have refrained
from introducing many names,
Numerous A great mannumber of villages
are studded all over the valley
44 but these possess no
permanence - and many
more existed previous
to the ^ Portuguese expedition of 1850 to
punish the Bangala - They
The people ^ were now gradually
returning to their former
abodes -

42
This valley as I have
before remarked is all
fertile in the extreme - My
men could never cease
admiring its capability for
yielding corn raising their
corn (holcus sorghum) and
despising the comparatively
limited cultivation of
the inhabitants - The Portuguese
informed me that no
manure is ever needed
but that the more the ground
is tilled the better it
yields - Virgin soil does
not give such a heavy
crop as an old garden
and judging from the
size of the maize and
manioc in the latter
I can readily believe the
statement - Cattle do well
R too But ^viewing the
valley as a whole it
may be said that its
agricultural and pastoral
45 riches are lying waste -
Both the Portuguese and their
descendants turn their
attention almost exclusively
to trade in wax and ivory
and though this country
would produceyield any
amount of corn and dairy-produce
43
the native Portuguese live chiefly
on manioc - and and the
Europeans purchase their
flour bread butter & cheese
from the Americans

As the traders of Cassange
were the first white
men we had come to
we sold the tusks belonging
to Sekeletu which we
had been brought to test
the difference of prices
between in the Makololo
and white men's country
The result was highly
satisfactory to my
companions as the
Portuguese give much
larger prices for ivory
than traders from the
Cape who having the
who labouring
under the disadvantage
of considerable
overland whose with considerable overland
expenses &ruinous
restrictions are enormous
can possibly give - Two
muskets, three small
barrels of gunpowder and
English calico and baize
46 sufficient to clother my
whole party with a large
bunches of beads all for one
tusk were
quite delightful for those
who had been accustomed
to give two tusks for one
gun - With the other three
another tusks we purchasedprocured calico
